​@Farwa R I am also not Adriene (lol) but I think there are LOTS of benefits to doing yoga when you a pregnant. I would say to keep the parts that feel comfortable, and modify the parts that require too much crunching or pressure or balance. What counts is that you are showing up and breathing and being calm and relaxed, and sharing your energy with everyone also doing the practice.

Fun fact for those interested in languages and imagery (as I am)
In Sanskrit or Hindi (which I speak) Bak = crane. Kak = crow. In the practicing of the asanas the poses are similar. And I really love the flow Adriene created to get us to the point of courage to try it. 😘👏🏼👏🏼
So some of us may have managed to straighten arms in the last pose rather like the long legged Crane = Bakasana. And some of us may have managed to balance using crooked arms looking more like the shorter legs of the Crow = Kakasana. Either way more power to you!

I'd like to share a little story about my yoga journey. :)

A few hours after yesterday's practice, I made a small movement while sitting at my computer. Suddenly, my neck was struck with a terrible pain. I could barely move my head and had the worst night's sleep, and it was no better in the morning. I have quite a bit of anxiety, but I managed to get myself to the physiotherapist the next morning in a bit of a panic.

That panic soon subsided. It was a GREAT visit (and not just because of the massage! XD). He showed me some neck stretches and strengthening exercises and said, echoing Adriene, that self-care and mindful movement is so important in dealing with injury and pain. He was also SO happy to hear that I'd been doing yoga every day for the past 10 days.

It really hit me then that I had learned to view pain as something fearful, indicative of danger, and to freeze up when it occurs. But some pain is just an alarm bell with no underlying harm, or harm that will heal with proper care and patience. A huge part of dealing with pain involves movement and being soft, kind, and yep -- having courage!

So instead of giving up on yoga entirely, I did one of Adriene's softer neck and shoulder practices that day, just to be safe. But today I decided to continue the 30 day journey. I really had to have courage this time -- not only to do these awesome yoga poses, but also to take initiative and change it up when the poses were not appropriate for me (the physio said to avoid putting too much weight on either side), and to be very aware and kind to my neck. I have been pushing too much on some of these exercises, and I am now much more aware of that.

I saw my physio again too, and the last thing he wrote on the take-home exercise notes was "Keep up the yoga! :)"

So thank you, Adriene. This truly is a journey, and like you said in this video, it takes real effort go inside and to deal with all the stuff we have built up inside our hearts and minds (and of course it takes effort to move our mindful butts now and again too). Much love to you and to everyone else practicing out there! <3

The next instant, I was laughing like a mad man.
Then I listened to you, Adriene. I truly listened to you. And I've had trouble holding my tears, since then. But these are good tears. They're okay. I'm okay.
